vectorData.altText: 1. Most brain capillaries are of the ______________ type.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
Thatâ€™s right!  Most brain capillaries are continuous, meaning that the endothelial cells are joined by tight junctions (TJs). TJs limit molecular movement via the paracellular route.

The first component of the BBB to be described is the blood-ISF barrier. 
Capillaries in neural tissue are of the continuous type,  meaning that the endothelial cells lining these vessels are joined by tight junctions (TJ). Tight junctions block the movement of molecules by the paracellular route, i.e. they block the passage of molecules between adjacent endothelial cells. 
This means that any molecules that pass between plasma and ISF must pass through the endothelial cells, i.e. by the transcellular route (dotted arrows). Such molecules must either be i) able to diffuse through the endothelial cell membrane, such as gases and lipid-soluble molecules, or ii) carried by specific transporters embedded in the endothelial cell membrane.
The formation of tight junctions is induced by contact between astrocytic end-feet and brain capillaries.
Thus, intact TJs between endothelial cells, and selective molecular transporters determine the composition of brain ISF.
